text: <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a target of pentoxifylline - mediated inhibition of T lymphocyte activation .
The possible clinical use of the methyl xanthine derivative , pentoxifylline ( PF ) , for the treatment of T cell - dependent diseases is being noted with increasing interest .
In this paper , we studied the molecular consequences of PF treatment during lymphocyte activation .

We found that in T cells , anti-CD3 - induced <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was blocked by PF , whereas the induction of other NF-kappaB family members was not significantly affected .

text: However , induction of NF-AT , which has the same signaling requirements as <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction , was not inhibited by PF .

Among genes that respond to these transcription factors , <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA induction was suppressed by PF , whereas <extra_id_0> IL-2R(alpha) chain <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA induction was not affected .

text: These observations implicated <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as an <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter factor , for which experimental support was obtained from transient transfection experiments .
In contrast with the observation in T cells , <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction was not blocked by PF in B cells .

text: The greater selectivity of PF , compared with FK506 , at both the molecular and cellular levels may prove advantageous in manipulating T cell responses in vivo .
